importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the day Nicolas Sarkozy entered jail, making him the first French ex-president to be imprisoned, a significant historical and political event.
This date marks the start of Sarkozy's presidency, contextualizing the political timeline and the events surrounding the campaign financing scandal that led to his imprisonment.
France's highest administrative court is scheduled to deliver its verdict on Sarkozy's appeal against the six-month jail term in the Bygmalion affair, a pivotal moment in his legal case.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2007 to 2012 covers Sarkozy's presidency and the emergence of the campaign financing scandal, which culminated in legal action after his term ended.
The current timeline reflects the ongoing legal and public scrutiny of Sarkozy post-presidency, including the prison sentence and appeals process.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy becomes the first French ex-president to go to jail, marking a historic shift in French political accountability.
Sarkozy is serving a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 campaign with Libyan funds linked to Muammar Gaddafi.
He was convicted of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, not of personally receiving the money.
The case involves a secret meeting between aides and Gaddafi’s intelligence officials via a Franco-Lebanese intermediary, Ziad Tiakeddine.
Sarkozy claims innocence and asserts the trial is politically motivated, citing deep sorrow for a 'France humiliated by revenge'.
He is currently in solitary confinement at La Santé prison, with limited contact and restricted movement, although he has basic rights and amenities.
Support from President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin signals political and institutional recognition of the case’s sensitivity.
France’s highest administrative court will deliver a verdict on Sarkozy’s appeal in late October 2025, which may overturn or uphold the conviction.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former president of France from 2007 to 2012, has become the first French ex-president to go to jail, serving a five-year sentence for criminal association in a secret campaign financing scheme involving Libyan funds from Muammar Gaddafi. Though he denies personal wrongdoing, he was convicted for his aides' role in arranging meetings with Gaddafi’s intelligence officials through intermediary Ziad Tiakeddine. Sarkozy is currently held in solitary confinement at La Santé prison, where he is isolated from other inmates and has limited contact with the outside world. He has appealed the conviction and is expected to receive a verdict from France’s highest administrative court in late October 2025. Despite the legal outcome, political figures like President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin have shown public support, highlighting the broader societal and political implications of the case.
title: Sarkozy enters jail over campaign financing - France's first ex-president behind bars
